title: Isaiah Chapter 43 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 43 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 43 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 43.

questions.question: Who does the LORD say He created and formed in Isaiah 43:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob and Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:1 states that the LORD created and formed Jacob and Israel.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 43:2, what will not happen when you pass through the rivers?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not overflow thee
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:2 promises that when passing through waters and rivers, they shall not overflow the person.

questions.question: What did God give for Israel as a ransom according to Isaiah 43:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt, Ethiopia, and Seba
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:3 mentions God gave Egypt for Israel's ransom, also Ethiopia and Seba.

questions.question: In Isaiah 43:4, why does God say He loves Israel?
options: Because Israel was precious and honorable
questions.correctAnswer: Because Israel was precious and honorable
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:4 says Israel was precious in God's sight and honorable, and therefore He loved them.

questions.question: From which directions will the LORD gather Israel as mentioned in Isaiah 43:5-6?
questions.correctAnswer: East, West, North, and South
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:5-6 states God will bring Israel's seed from the east and gather from the west, commanding north and south to bring His sons and daughters.

questions.question: Who are called by God's name and created for His glory according to Isaiah 43:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Everyone called by His name
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:7 declares that everyone called by God's name was created for His glory.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 43:10, who are God's witnesses?
options: You (Israel) and my servant whom I have chosen
questions.correctAnswer: You (Israel) and my servant whom I have chosen
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:10 states that Israel and God's chosen servant are His witnesses.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 43:11 says there is no savior besides the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:11 clearly states that beside the LORD there is no savior.

questions.question: Who does the LORD say He has sent to Babylon in Isaiah 43:14?
options: Your redeemer, the Holy One of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Your redeemer, the Holy One of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:14 identifies the LORD as the redeemer who sent to Babylon.

questions.question: What did God make a way through according to Isaiah 43:16?
questions.correctAnswer: The sea and mighty waters
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:16 says the LORD makes a way in the sea and a path in mighty waters.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Isaiah 43:19: 'Behold, I will do a new thing; now it shall spring forth; shall ye not know it? I will even make a way in the ______, and rivers in the desert.'
questions.correctAnswer: wilderness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:19 states that God will make a way in the wilderness and rivers in the desert.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 43:21, for what purpose were the people formed?
questions.correctAnswer: To show forth God's praise
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:21 says God formed the people for Himself, that they would show forth His praise.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 43:22 says Israel has called upon God faithfully.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:22 states that Israel has not called upon God and has been weary of Him.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 43:25, who blotteth out transgressions?
questions.correctAnswer: I, even I (the LORD)
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:25 says the LORD Himself blotteth out transgressions for His own sake.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 43:18 instructs to remember the former things and consider the things of old.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:18 instructs not to remember the former things nor consider the things of old.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 43 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 43 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Isaiah 43, what biblical truth would you share about God's presence in difficulties?
options: God promises to be with us through trials and protect us
God will remove all trials instantly if we pray hard enough
Trials mean God has abandoned us
We must face trials completely alone
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to be with us through trials and protect us
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:2 assures that when we pass through waters and fire, God will be with us and protect us. This teaches us to trust in God's presence during hardships (Isaiah 43:1, 43:2, 43:5).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 43 teach about God's love and value for His people in the context of family and identity?
options: We are precious and honored in God's sight, called by name as His own
Our value depends on our achievements
God loves everyone equally but does not claim anyone personally
Family ties are more important than God's calling
questions.correctAnswer: We are precious and honored in God's sight, called by name as His own
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:1 and 43:4 emphasize that God has redeemed us, called us by name, and loves us dearly, showing the importance of our identity in Him (Isaiah 43:1, 43:4, 43:7).

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged about evangelism. What encouragement does Isaiah 43 give about being God's witness?
options: We are chosen by God to be His witnesses and to declare His truth
Only pastors and leaders can be witnesses
Witnessing should be done only when convenient
questions.correctAnswer: We are chosen by God to be His witnesses and to declare His truth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:10 highlights that believers are God's witnesses and servants chosen to know, believe, and proclaim Him, encouraging active evangelism (Isaiah 43:10, 43:12, 43:21).

questions.question: How does this chapter encourage perseverance and trust in God's sovereign power?
options: God works powerfully and no one can prevent His plans
We must rely solely on human strength
God's power is limited by circumstances
Perseverance depends only on our willpower
questions.correctAnswer: God works powerfully and no one can prevent His plans
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:13 teaches that God is sovereign and will accomplish His purposes, encouraging believers to trust Him even in difficult times (Isaiah 43:13, 43:14, 43:17).

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 43, what should be our attitude toward past failures and sins in our spiritual walk?
options: God blots out transgressions and does not remember sins
God punishes repeatedly for past mistakes
Forgiveness is impossible for repeated sins
questions.correctAnswer: God blots out transgressions and does not remember sins
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:25 reveals God's willingness to forgive and remove sins for His own sake, encouraging us to seek repentance and live in grace (Isaiah 43:25, 43:26, 43:24).

questions.question: A believer struggles with fear about the future. What biblical truth from Isaiah 43 offers comfort and hope?
options: God will bring His people from all directions and be with them
Fear is a sign of weak faith and should be ignored
The future is uncertain and God may not intervene
We must rely on our own plans without trusting God
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring His people from all directions and be with them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:5-6 assures that God will gather His people from east, west, north, and south, showing His care and control over the future (Isaiah 43:5, 43:6, 43:19).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 43 instruct us about humility and reliance on God rather than trusting in idols or other gods?
options: There is no God besides the LORD; He alone is Savior
Other gods can also save us
We should trust our own wisdom over God
Idols have power to protect us
questions.correctAnswer: There is no God besides the LORD; He alone is Savior
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:10-11 clearly states that the LORD is the only God and Savior, teaching humility and sole reliance on Him (Isaiah 43:10, 43:11, 43:12).

questions.question: What practical lesson about obedience and worship can be learned from Isaiah 43 regarding honoring God with sacrifices?
options: God desires sincere obedience more than ritual sacrifices
God is pleased only with elaborate offerings
questions.correctAnswer: God desires sincere obedience more than ritual sacrifices
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:22-24 rebukes Israel for failing to honor God properly, showing that true devotion is more than external rituals (Isaiah 43:22-24, 43:26).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 43 teaches that God will do a new thing and provide for His people even in difficult, barren places.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:19-20 declares that God will do new things, making a way in the wilderness and rivers in the desert, providing for His chosen people (Isaiah 43:19, 43:20).

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 43, God does not take personal responsibility for the redemption of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:1 and 43:14 show that God Himself redeems and sends judgment for the sake of His people, demonstrating His active role in their salvation (Isaiah 43:1, 43:14, 43:15).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 43:21 says, "This people have I ______ for myself; they shall shew forth my praise."
questions.correctAnswer: formed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:21 states that God has formed His people for Himself so that they may declare His praise, highlighting the purpose of God's calling (Isaiah 43:21, 43:7).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 43 encourage believers to respond to God's forgiveness and grace in their relationships with others?
options: We should forgive others as God forgives us
We should hold grudges to protect ourselves
Forgiveness is optional and based on feelings
Only God can forgive; we need not forgive others
questions.correctAnswer: We should forgive others as God forgives us
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:25 emphasizes God's forgiveness of our sins, which teaches us to extend forgiveness to others as part of living in obedience and love (Isaiah 43:25, 43:26).

questions.question: A believer feels weary in prayer and devotion. What does Isaiah 43 say about calling upon God and trusting His faithfulness?
options: We should call upon God and seek justification through Him
Prayer is not necessary for God's favor
Devotion is only for spiritual leaders
questions.correctAnswer: We should call upon God and seek justification through Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:26 urges believers to put God in remembrance and plead together, showing the importance of persistent prayer and trust (Isaiah 43:26, 43:25).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 43 teach about God's faithfulness despite Israel's repeated sins and failures?
options: God forgives and continues to work despite their transgressions
questions.correctAnswer: God forgives and continues to work despite their transgressions
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:27-28 shows that although Israel and their leaders sinned, God still acts by rebuking and allowing restoration, demonstrating His faithfulness (Isaiah 43:25, 43:27-28).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 43 illustrate the importance of integrity and honesty in acknowledging God as Creator and King?
options: Acknowledging God as Creator and King is foundational to faith and life
One can live righteously without recognizing God
God created only some people, not all
Kingdom authority is irrelevant to spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledging God as Creator and King is foundational to faith and life
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:15 declares the LORD as Holy One, Creator of Israel, and King, affirming that recognizing God's authority is essential for faithful living (Isaiah 43:15, 43:7).

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 43 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 43.

questions.question: In Isaiah 43:1, God addresses Israel by two different names. What is the significance of these names in the context of Israel's identity?
options: Jacob and Israel represent the nation and the individual leader
Jacob and Israel signify the transformation from struggle to divine election
Jacob and Israel are used interchangeably without distinct meaning
Jacob refers to the northern kingdom, Israel to the southern kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob and Israel signify the transformation from struggle to divine election
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:1 calls Israel by 'Jacob' and 'Israel,' highlighting the transformation from the man who struggled with God (Jacob) to the chosen people (Israel). This reflects both historical and theological identity.

questions.question: Isaiah 43:2 uses the imagery of water and fire. What type of literary device is primarily employed in this verse?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:2 uses parallelism by pairing water and fire experiences to emphasize God's protection in adversity, a common Hebrew poetic device.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern nations are mentioned in Isaiah 43:3 as being given for Israel's ransom?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt, Ethiopia, and Seba
questions.explanation: Verse 3 explicitly mentions Egypt, Ethiopia, and Seba as given for Israel's ransom, reflecting the geopolitical context of Israel surrounded by these powerful nations.

questions.question: In Isaiah 43:4, God declares Israel as precious and loved. How does this relate typologically to the New Testament concept of the church?
options: It foreshadows the church as God's beloved bride
It contradicts the New Testament view of the church
It refers only to ancient Israel without future application
It predicts the destruction of the church
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the church as God's beloved bride
questions.explanation: The language of preciousness and love in Isaiah 43:4 typologically points to the church as the beloved bride of Christ, a theme developed in the New Testament.

questions.question: Isaiah 43:5-6 describes a gathering of Israel from all directions. Which New Testament event does this prophecy most closely parallel?
options: The ingathering of the elect in Revelation 7
questions.correctAnswer: The ingathering of the elect in Revelation 7
questions.explanation: The gathering of sons and daughters from all ends of the earth in Isaiah 43:5-6 parallels Revelation 7's depiction of the redeemed from every tribe and nation, emphasizing God's saving plan.

questions.question: In Isaiah 43:7, God says He created each person for His glory. What Hebrew word for 'glory' is implied here and what does it signify?
questions.correctAnswer: Kavod, indicating weightiness or honor
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'kavod' is often translated as glory and signifies the weightiness, honor, and splendor of God, which believers are created to reflect.

questions.question: Isaiah 43:8 challenges the blind with eyes and the deaf with ears to testify. What is the literary significance of this paradox?
options: It emphasizes spiritual blindness and deafness despite physical senses
It mocks those who pretend to see and hear
It is a straightforward description of physical disabilities
It signifies the rejection of foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes spiritual blindness and deafness despite physical senses
questions.explanation: The paradox in Isaiah 43:8 highlights that some people, though physically capable, are spiritually blind and deaf, unable to perceive God's truth.

questions.question: Isaiah 43:10 declares Israel as God's witnesses and servant. How does this role relate to the concept of covenant in the Hebrew Bible?
options: Witnesses confirm the covenant relationship and God's unique identity
Witnesses are unrelated to covenant theology
questions.correctAnswer: Witnesses confirm the covenant relationship and God's unique identity
questions.explanation: In Hebrew covenant theology, witnesses validate the agreement; Israel's role as God's witness in Isaiah 43:10 confirms the exclusive covenant relationship and God's sovereign identity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 43:11, there are many saviors besides the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:11 clearly states, 'I, even I, am the LORD; and beside me there is no saviour,' emphasizing God's exclusivity as savior.

questions.question: Isaiah 43:13 uses the phrase 'before the day was I am he.' What theological concept is this phrase emphasizing?
questions.correctAnswer: God's eternal existence and self-existence
questions.explanation: The phrase in Isaiah 43:13 affirms God's eternal nature, existing before time and unchanging, a core theological concept of divine self-existence.

questions.question: Isaiah 43:14 references God sending to Babylon and bringing down nobles and Chaldeans. What historical event is this likely alluding to?
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian exile and conquest
questions.explanation: Verse 14 alludes to God's judgment on Babylon, referencing the historical Babylonian conquest and exile of Israel, a major event in the ancient Near East context.

questions.question: Isaiah 43:16 speaks of making a way in the sea and a path in mighty waters. How does this imagery relate to earlier biblical salvation narratives?
options: It recalls the Exodus crossing of the Red Sea
It describes a literal canal being built
questions.correctAnswer: It recalls the Exodus crossing of the Red Sea
questions.explanation: The imagery in Isaiah 43:16 echoes God's deliverance of Israel through the Red Sea during the Exodus, a foundational salvation event in biblical history.

questions.question: In Isaiah 43:18-19, God says He will do a new thing and make a way in the wilderness. What literary theme is this an example of?
questions.correctAnswer: Renewal and restoration
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 express the theme of God's power to bring renewal and restoration, making a way and rivers in the desert, symbolizing hope and new beginnings.

questions.question: Isaiah 43:21 states, 'This people have I formed for myself; they shall shew forth my praise.' What does this reveal about the purpose of Israel's formation?
options: To glorify God and declare His praise
questions.correctAnswer: To glorify God and declare His praise
questions.explanation: The verse reveals Israel was formed to glorify God and publicly demonstrate His praise, underscoring Israel's role as God's covenant people.

questions.question: Isaiah 43:25 contains God's declaration to blot out transgressions for His own sake. How does this relate to the New Testament doctrine of atonement?
options: It foreshadows Christ's sacrifice for sin
It denies the need for forgiveness
It emphasizes human works for salvation
It refers only to Old Testament sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Christ's sacrifice for sin
questions.explanation: God's promise to blot out transgressions in Isaiah 43:25 anticipates the New Testament teaching of atonement through Christ's sacrifice, which removes sin for God's glory.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 43 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 43 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 43, what reason does God give for telling Israel not to fear?
options: Because He has redeemed them and called them by name
Because they are stronger than their enemies
Because they will receive great wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Because He has redeemed them and called them by name
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:1 states that God commands Israel not to fear because He has redeemed them and called them by name, emphasizing God's personal relationship and salvation. This is consistent with Exodus 14:13, Deuteronomy 31:6, Psalm 27:1, and John 6:37 where God’s redemption and calling give confidence and remove fear.

questions.question: What does God promise to Israel when they pass through waters and fire, according to Isaiah 43?
options: They shall not be overwhelmed or burned
They will be purified by fire and water
They will walk on water and fire
They will be tested but must endure alone
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be overwhelmed or burned
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:2 promises that when Israel passes through waters and fire, they will not be overwhelmed or burned, signifying God's protective presence. This reflects themes in Psalm 66:12, Daniel 3:25, Romans 8:35-39, and 1 Corinthians 10:13 where God preserves and delivers His people through trials.

questions.question: In Isaiah 43, God identifies Himself with several titles. Which of the following is NOT one of them?
questions.correctAnswer: The Redeemer of Egypt
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:3 calls God the Holy One of Israel and thy Saviour, and Isaiah 43:15 calls Him the Creator of Israel. He says He gave Egypt for their ransom but does not call Himself 'Redeemer of Egypt.' This is aligned with Exodus 15:2, Isaiah 45:21, John 4:42, and Revelation 1:8 where God’s titles emphasize His holiness, salvation, and creation of Israel.

questions.question: What is the significance of God saying 'I have called you by my name; you are mine' in Isaiah 43:1?
options: It expresses God's covenant ownership and intimate relationship with Israel
It means Israel must legally change their names
It refers to a secret code known only to priests
It implies Israel must worship other gods
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses God's covenant ownership and intimate relationship with Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:1 shows God's personal redemption and covenantal belonging of Israel, marking them as His own. This is consistent with Exodus 6:7, Leviticus 26:12, Romans 8:15-17, and 1 John 3:1 where God's naming signifies relationship, adoption, and sanctification.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 43 describe God's action toward the nations and their idols in verse 9?
options: God challenges nations to prove their gods' power, showing His exclusive sovereignty
God encourages idol worship along with Him
God ignores the nations and their idols
God accepts all gods as equal
questions.correctAnswer: God challenges nations to prove their gods' power, showing His exclusive sovereignty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:9 challenges all nations to present their witnesses or declare former things, emphasizing God's uniqueness and sovereignty. This theme of God's incomparable nature appears in Deuteronomy 32:39, 1 Kings 18:21, Isaiah 44:6, and John 17:3.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 43:10 say about Israel’s role in relation to God?
options: They are God's witnesses and chosen servant to know and believe Him
They are to build temples for all gods
They are to remain silent about God
They are only to serve earthly kings
questions.correctAnswer: They are God's witnesses and chosen servant to know and believe Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:10 describes Israel as God's witnesses and chosen servant, tasked with knowing, believing, and understanding God’s identity. This relates to Exodus 19:5-6, Isaiah 49:6, Acts 1:8, and Hebrews 3:1 where God's people testify to His character and salvation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I, even I, am the LORD; and beside me there is no ______.' (Isaiah 43:11)
questions.correctAnswer: saviour
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:11 clearly states 'beside me there is no saviour,' affirming God's unique role as the only true Savior. This is echoed in Deuteronomy 4:35, Hosea 13:4, John 14:6, and Acts 4:12 emphasizing salvation exclusively through God.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 43:13, what attribute of God is highlighted in relation to His sovereign power over history?
options: He has existed before time and none can prevent His work
He depends on human effort to succeed
He is uncertain about future events
He is limited by other gods
questions.correctAnswer: He has existed before time and none can prevent His work
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:13 emphasizes God's eternal existence and unstoppable power, reflecting His sovereignty over history. This aligns with Psalm 90:2, Isaiah 44:6, Revelation 1:8, and Romans 8:38-39 which affirm God's eternal nature and omnipotence.

questions.question: What historical event does God reference in Isaiah 43:14 as an act of redemption for Israel?
options: The sending to Babylon and defeat of its nobles and Chaldeans
questions.correctAnswer: The sending to Babylon and defeat of its nobles and Chaldeans
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:14 mentions God sending to Babylon and bringing down their nobles, pointing to God's judgment and redemptive deliverance of Israel from exile. This corresponds with Jeremiah 29:10, Daniel 9:2, Ezra 1:1, and 2 Chronicles 36:22 where Babylon’s captivity and God’s redemptive plan are key themes.

questions.question: What metaphor does God use in Isaiah 43:16-17 to describe His power over enemies?
options: Making a way in the sea and quenching the enemy's army like tow
Building walls of fire around Israel
Making enemies into pillars of salt
questions.correctAnswer: Making a way in the sea and quenching the enemy's army like tow
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:16-17 uses the imagery of making a path in the sea and extinguishing chariots and horses like dry tow (flax) to illustrate God’s sovereign defeat of enemies, echoing Exodus 14:21-28, Psalm 77:19, Nahum 1:3, and Romans 8:31.

questions.question: What new thing does God declare He will do in Isaiah 43:19?
options: Make a way in the wilderness and rivers in the desert
Bring a new king from Egypt
Establish a new covenant with other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Make a way in the wilderness and rivers in the desert
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:19 proclaims God will create a new way in the wilderness and rivers in the desert as a sign of restoration and divine provision. This is consistent with Exodus 15:22-27, Isaiah 35:6, John 7:38, and Revelation 22:1-2 where God transforms desolation into life-giving blessing.

questions.question: Who are described as honoring God because He gives waters in the wilderness in Isaiah 43:20?
options: Beasts of the field, dragons, and owls
questions.correctAnswer: Beasts of the field, dragons, and owls
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:20 mentions wild animals such as beasts, dragons, and owls honoring God due to His provision of water in the wilderness, illustrating all creation recognizing God's sustaining power. This theme appears in Psalm 148:7-10, Job 12:7-10, Romans 8:19-22, and Revelation 5:13.

questions.question: What reason does God give for Israel’s failure expressed in Isaiah 43:22-24?
options: Israel did not call upon God or honor Him with offerings
Israel was too wealthy to need God
questions.correctAnswer: Israel did not call upon God or honor Him with offerings
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:22-24 accuses Israel of not calling on God or honoring Him with sacrifices, showing a spiritual failure. This is consistent with Hosea 6:6, Amos 5:21-24, Micah 6:6-8, and Matthew 9:13 emphasizing the importance of heartfelt worship over ritual.

questions.question: How does God describe His forgiveness of Israel’s sins in Isaiah 43:25?
options: He blots out transgressions and will not remember their sins
He punishes all sins without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: He blots out transgressions and will not remember their sins
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:25 declares God’s forgiveness where He blots out transgressions and chooses not to remember sins, highlighting divine mercy. This is parallel to Psalm 103:12, Jeremiah 31:34, Hebrews 8:12, and 1 John 1:9 where God’s gracious forgiveness is taught.

questions.question: What plea does God make in Isaiah 43:26 to Israel regarding their relationship with Him?
options: To remember God and plead together for justification
To build altars on every hill
To seek other gods for help
questions.correctAnswer: To remember God and plead together for justification
questions.explanation: Isaiah 43:26 calls Israel to remember God and engage in a mutual pleading, implying repentance and justification. This accords with Deuteronomy 4:7, Psalm 25:7, Isaiah 1:18, and Romans 8:33 where God invites His people to reconcile and be justified.
